title: Selective Masking Adversarial Attack on Automatic Speech Recognition Systems
author: Zheng Fang (Wuhan University), Bowen Li (Wuhan University), Shenyi Zhang (Wuhan University), Lingchen Zhao (Wuhan University), Tao Wang (Wuhan University), Zhangyi Wang (Wuhan University)
relevance_why: The paper presents a new attack method for audio adversarial attacks that addresses dual-source scenarios. This could inform future research on robustness in audio systems and could enhance Haohe Liu's work on audio restoration and generation by providing insights into adversarial robustness.
background: The paper investigates how to manipulate automatic speech recognition systems to only recognize one speaker while masking another in a dual-source audio environment.
contribution: This paper introduces the Selective Masking Adversarial attack (SMA attack) to solve the challenge of recognizing one speaker in dual-source audio, achieving a 100% success rate in attacks on various ASR systems.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily targeted single-source audio, which limits their applicability in real-world dual-source scenarios where multiple speakers are present.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by implementing a dual-source initialization method and a selective masking optimization algorithm, enabling successful recognition of selected audio while masking others.

key_innovation: Combines dual-source audio initialization with a targeted masking approach to generate adversarial examples that remain imperceptible to human listeners.
real_world_impact: By demonstrating the potential vulnerabilities of ASR systems in dual-source scenarios, this work raises awareness about security in speech recognition technologies and could guide future improvements in ASR system robustness.
limitations: No limitations were explicitly mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.Selective Masking Adversarial attack: **Selective Masking Adversarial attack (SMA attack)** is a method designed to manipulate sound inputs so that an ASR system recognizes only selected audio while masking other audio sources.
